posts.content:
I've been mulling around all sorts of ideas about builds (you see what happens when I still can't actually play the game!), and one that popped its head up was a sniper assassin. I'd be thinking an Elf Bard/ AA/ Assassin (no xp penalty due to 2 prestige classes). However, a few questions spring to mind before I go wasting years of my life on this.

First, having noticed that there is no such build available through Hip's ECB Guild Filter, is it just a pants idea?

Second (and let's assume I'm ok to continue after the first question), would it require a meat-shield companion - which kind of goes against the "lone assassin" ethic?

Third, other than for RP reasons, would Rogue be a more sensible option than Assassin (no DA, but retain sneaks and get Evasion, more skill pts etc)? I appreciate I may have to switch to Half-Elf for this.

Fourth, while I know the first 5 levels at least would need to be Bard, so I'd need a minimum of 11 Charisma, thus certainly impacting on min/max-ing, but what sort of split might be best - given that I'd be going heavy in either Ass or AA (probably AA)? My current thinking is something like Bard 9/AA 22/Ass 9, but more than happy to change that.

Fifth and finally, would it make more sense to drop Ass for SD? This would enable more AA levels (assuming I'd only be using SD for HiPS, thus requiring only 1 or 2 levels). I could still RP a vengeful outsider taking out old foes - real and perceived - but wouldn't need to be an evil-weevil?

Any and all advice welcome!

Cheers

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
First Stag, I will point you to the A Shot In The dark thread from january.
The Idea is not bad at all. I posted an Assassin heavy build there, and it works well.
Both AA and Assassin are classes that work at their best with many class levels. In the build I posted, I chose to focus on Assassin and use AA to boost AB and base damage some, and not have to rely on a +5 bow to piece premonition.
You know me; I don't use meat shields for stalkers. I used stealth, corner hiding and speed once i got haste. Corner hiding is much easier when you attack from some distance and have a head start.
As for Rogue versus Assassin as main class.
Rogue is a great class and all with skill points galore and many useful bonus feats. And SA does just as much damage as DA. And you can take Rogue at level 1 with the boost to skillpoints, and early SA. Rogue even gets evasion and can qualify for ED all on its own.
What assassin gets is the paralysis, the undispellable Improved invisibility and Great dexterity as an epic bonus feat. The high dexterity makes it possible to end up with a warrior like AB.

If you want AA to be the main class for your archer, then Bard/AA builds have great flexibility. You can pick almost any 3rd class, if you want any at all. In such a build both Rogue and SD have more to offer than Assassin.
A high AA class will give the damage you need. You may add fighter for EWS, but you don't need it.

Bard/AA/SD is the only practical HIPS AA (Sorcerer and Wizard based builds are not). I have played several of those AA builds using HIPS for crowd control, and I can recommend it. 10 levels of SD also let you have ED for your archer. 10 SD levels take away some of the AA sting, but adds a lot to defense.

Eeevil or not? Bard/AA can be as good or bad as you wish.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Thanks, Mick! It's actually tomorrow, but friends couldn't make drinks on a Tuesday, so...

Anyway, bit of a sore head today. So, to help me work through it I had a crack at pulling together a Bard 6/ AA 25/ Ass 9. (I get what you said about not needing more than Bard 5, but given that they'd have to be the first 5 levels in order to get the requisite 8 in Hide and MS, and that neither AA nor Ass has Spellcraft as a class skill, I decided to pop another level in at 37 to get +8 to saves vs spells, as well as topping-off Tumble as I finished Ass levels at 32.)

It was very much a curate's egg - good in parts. I went with stats of Str 12, Dex 18(34), Con 12, Wis 8, Int 14, Cha 12. This all resulted in a perfectly respectable +55 AB with +13 EA and 17d6 Imbue Arrow explosion, 32 naked AC, 258 skill points - so I could max Hide, MS, Spell, Spot, Tumble and UMD, with a few for Perform for the nursery rhyme rather than song. Reflex save was strong (37). HPs could have been worse (370 with Toughness, which could be swapped for something more useful like Expertise or Finesse to help with any melee). I got PBS, Rapid Shot, Called Shot, WF, Imp Crit and Blind Fight, and in Epic: 6 Great Dex, EWF, EP and Armour Skin.

However, the other 2 saves were crap at best (F 20, W 18). With no Evasion and a stinky Fort save, I really couldn't get caught in melee. But the real kicker was Death Attack. Only 5d6, and with a DC of 21. Kind of ruined the point of taking Assassin at all.

So, I'm now going to follow sage earlier counsel from both Empyre and yourself and go more Ass-heavy (which is not the same as having a fat arse). I'm off to try a Bard 6/ Ass 23/ AA11 to see what happens...

Cheers!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Alright, I've had a blast at the aforementioned Bard 6/ Ass 23/ AA 11 for compare and contrast purposes. I've also just had a look back at Mick's build from the Shot in the Dark (Bard 5/ Ass 26/ AA 9), and I'm pleasantly surprised with what I've cobbled together. It needs tuning, but it's still not too shabby.

I started with the same stats as above, but took Dex up to 36 at the expense of Armour Skin. This time, obviously, the AB took a hit: +49 with +6 EA and 10d6 Imbue Arrow explosion. Naked AC dipped 1 to 31 (+1 Dex, -2 AS). Other than the Reflex save (38), the rest remained crap (F20, W17), with +8 vs spells and +11 vs poison. The skill points remain the same and are distributed similarly (a few minor differences). With Toughness, I had 342 HPs. The only differences in feats was the loss of AS, but got Great Dex VIII.

But Death Attack was significantly better - 12d6 with a DC of 35.

So, I guess the big question is AB or DA - where would you go?

Cheers
